poem:
Settlers and Soldiers  

In Susiya, beneath the evening's  
quiet breath,  
shadows came, faceless,  
bearing batons, slicing night  
like knives through  
tomorrow's dreams.  
The land, stones witnessed,  
whisper histories—  
a crack of rifles,  
a rupture of fasts.  
Ramadan's tender edge  
meets resistance,  
in soil, mingled,  
where peace  
grieves silently.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘This is no isolated event’: attack on Palestinian director brings rising settler violence into focus It was around 6pm, just after its Palestinian residents had finished their daily Ramadan fast, dozens of masked Israeli settlers, armed with batons, knives and assault rifles, entered the West Bank village of Susiya in the rural Masafer Yatta area of the south Hebron hills. Among them were a group of Israeli soldiers who escorted the settlers into the village". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
